news.headline: AI Weekly: major deals and Pope Leo's warning
news.summary: STORY: Could Meta rival Nvidia? And what the Pope thinks about artificial intelligence. :: AI WeeklyThis is AI Weekly. Meta Platforms is in talks with Google to spend billions of dollars on the company's chips for use in its data centers starting from 2027.That's according to The Information.If confirmed it could pitch Google as a serious rival to semiconductor giant Nvidia.The report said talks also involve Meta renting chips from Google Cloud as early as next year.:: FileU.S. President Donald Trump signed an executive order to launch a government-wide effort to build an integrated AI platform.It's to harness federal scientific datasets to train next-generation technologies.The effort is called the Genesis Mission.It aims to transform research and speed discoveries by using massive government scientific datasets.:: FileTrump directed the U.S. Energy Department and U.S. National Laboratories to, quote, "unite America’s brightest minds and most powerful computers.":: FileThe Kremlin says Russian President Vladimir Putin doesn't use AI tools himself, but officials who work for him do.Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov added the Kremlin used AI tools to help sort through citizens' questions during Putin's annual question-and-answer event.:: FilePutin last week called for a national task force to coordinate Russia's work on homegrown generative AI models.He said they were vital to preserving Russian sovereignty.Alphabet is on track to hit a historic $4 trillion market valuation.It's been powered by an impressive year-long rally fueled by the Google parent's sharpened focus on AI tools.The firm joins an elite club of Big Tech companies racing to dominate the booming technology as AI continues to attract Wall Street this year.Leo, the first U.S. pope, discussed AI with 15,000 of the country's youth via a video call.It came during a live transmission from the Vatican to a national Catholic youth conference in Indiana.Leo told the young viewers AI is "becoming one of the defining features of our time."But he cautioned it must be used responsibly."In your education. Make the most of this time. A.I. can process information quickly, but it cannot replace human intelligence and don't ask it to do your homework for you. It cannot offer real wisdom. It misses a very important human element. A.I. will not judge between what is truly right and wrong.”

news.headline: Big Tech starts complying with Australia's teen social media ban
news.summary: STORY: Australian teenagers are set to lose their social media accounts, with a ban on young users set to kick in from December 10. Over the coming days, online platforms like TikTok, Snapchat, Meta and Instagram will notify more than a million teen account holders in the country. Users under the age of 16 must choose an option: Download data, freeze their profiles, or lose everything under the world-first ban on kids using social media.Based on information from insiders, the big platforms plan to deactivate accounts for users under the age of 16.Australia's other 20 million social media users should face no big changes.The move puts the nation out front in shielding young people from online risks.Earlier this year, platforms had warned of total chaos, fearing that they could lose users and face $32 million fines for breaking the rules.They said required age checks would mean constant logins, invade privacy and often be wrong or easy to dodge.But now, firms will use existing software that guesses ages from user habits, instead of asking for birth dates all the time.They will generally only push people to special age-check apps if someone complains about being blocked by mistake.The setup might hit snags at first.Age-check apps which are being deployed at scale for the first time can make mistakes.La Trobe University AI professor Daswin De Silva explains:"One of the challenges with age verification also is this band between 15, 16, 17, how do you distinguish 15 from 16 to 17. So a lot of the technological methods of age verification will fail in that narrow band and there might be false positives where certain individuals who are over 16, slightly over 16 will be banned from these platforms because their content was classified as relevant to under an 16 sort of target demographic.""It's probably going to be service distortion, service failure for a couple of days or weeks maybe until the platforms figure this out, and we'll see a lot of articles on media and maybe on social media itself of false positives."Meta, Snapchat, TikTok and Google declined to comment.The law states that such platforms must take "reasonable steps" to block minors.If the rollout goes smoothly, it could guide the world in cutting kids' exposure to harms like bullying or weight issues from screens.The UK and France added age gates for porn earlier this year. Then in November, Denmark said it would ban under-15s from social media.

news.headline: Shareholders of Union Pacific, Norfolk Southern support $85 billion rail merger
news.summary: Shareholders of Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern backed the railroads’ proposed $85 billion merger to create the nation’s first coast-to-coast rail network.  Roughly 99% of both railroads’ shareholders voted to support the largest rail merger in history Friday, but the U.S. Surface Transportation Board must still approve it before the deal can be completed.  Union Pacific CEO Jim Vena said, “Our shareholders see the value and understand this merger will unlock new opportunities to enhance service, growth and innovation."
